channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: The U.S. economy continues to power through the trade and immigration shocks of 2025, defying widespread expectations of a slowdown or even a recession
item.description: The unrelenting American consumer spends through a sour mood and a cooling labor market.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Wolfe

item.title: Financial Services Roundup: Market Talk
item.description: Find insight on U.S. home prices, retail sales and more in the latest Market Talks covering financial services.

item.title: U.S. economy posts robust growth in the third quarter, growing at an annual 4.3% rate
item.description: A long-delayed government report showed GDP grew at an annual 4.3% rate for the July through September quarter, beating expectations.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: Bank of Canada Officials Unsure on Future Direction of Rates, Minutes Say
item.description: Policymakers were reluctant to predict whether the next change in interest rates would be up or down, citing volatile data and elevated trade-policy uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: Canada GDP Edges Up After Sharp Contraction in October
item.description: Canada’s economy is on track to shrink slightly in the final quarter of 2025, with the steepest contraction in almost three years notched in October and early signs pointing to only a modest recovery last month.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: Consumer Confidence Falls as Jobs, Economic Worries Persist
item.description: Consumer sentiment in the U.S. weakened for a fifth consecutive month in December, amid enduring concerns over jobs and business conditions, a monthly survey said.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Canada’s Consumer Heads Into 2026 on Firmer Footing
item.description: Canada’s consumer is exiting 2025 in better shape compared with earlier in the year after shrugging off concerns of a trade war and other macroeconomic concerns that had weighed on spending.
item.dc:creator: Adriano Marchese

item.title: The U.S. labor market is ending 2025 on a sour note: Many companies trimmed head count and wage gains slowed.
item.description: Unemployment rose and wage growth shrank this year, potentially setting up an even rougher 2026.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: China Vanke’s Brewing Crisis Suggests Limited Property Easing to Come
item.description: Many of China’s other large developers have already defaulted, and a Vanke collapse would raise questions about how policymakers plan to address the real-estate slump as it drags on into a sixth year in 2026.

item.title: Cleveland Fed President Beth Hammack said she doesn’t see any need to change interest rates for several months in an interview with The Wall Street Journal
item.description: The Cleveland Fed president, who will vote on rates in 2026, said she is taking November’s cooler inflation reading “with a grain of salt.”
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Millions of homeowners are still locked into ultralow mortgage rates they don’t want to give up
item.description: Nearly 30 million households, or 54% of primary mortgage-holders, have mortgage rates at or below 4%.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: U.S. Labor Market Softened in October, November
item.description: The Conference Board’s Employment Trends Index declined to 105.80 in a joint number for both months, fueling further concerns about hiring after the unemployment rate edged higher.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Consumer Sentiment Rose in December but Remains Dim, Michigan Survey Suggests
item.description: Consumers’ economic mood recovered slightly in December but remained broadly gloomy as households face drawn-out inflation and a frustrating labor market for job seekers.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Home sales rose in November for the third straight month, with lower mortgage rates injecting some fresh momentum into the long sluggish housing market
item.description: Sales hit their highest level since February, after lower mortgage rates injected some fresh momentum into the long sluggish housing market.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: Russia’s Central Bank Cuts Key Rate, But Policy to Stay Tight
item.description: The bank is loosening the restraints to prevent the economy from overheating as the government spends heavily on its full-scale invasion of Ukraine and workers become scarce.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: EU Delays Mercosur Deal Sign-Off to January
item.description: Commission president Ursula von der Leyen said the signature was pushed out to January to give a few more weeks to address some outlying issues with member states.
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: German Consumer Sentiment Sinks to Near Two-Year Low
item.description: Economic uncertainty and a jump in the desire to save rather than spend drove sentiment to a 21-month low.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Rate rises in Japan ripple through global markets and might even push up the cost of borrowing in the U.S.
item.description: Rate rises in Japan ripple through global markets and might even push up the cost of borrowing in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Jason Douglas

item.title: Consumer prices rose 2.7% in November from a year earlier, slowing from 3% in September
item.description: Consumer prices rose 2.7% in November from a year earlier, according to a delayed government report, slowing from 3% in September.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: The Bank of Mexico lowered its benchmark interest rate as expected Thursday in a 12th consecutive cut, while signaling a possible pause before lowering the rate further in 2026
item.description: The central bank votes 4-1 to lower the benchmark rate target to 7% from 7.25%.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Harrup

item.title: Swiss Watch Industry’s Tough Year Continues as U.S. Exports Drop by Half
item.description: The key industry for the country was track to book a fall over a year marked by a sharp impact from U.S. trade tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Japan Exports Growth Streak Continues, Boosting Rate Hike Hopes
item.description: Exports rose for a third straight month in November, further supporting expectations for an interest-rate hike this week.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: Tuesday’s jobs report was the latest ominous sign in an era of big corporate layoff announcements and CEOs warning that AI will replace workers
item.description: Office workers are filled with anxiety as sectors such as information and financial activities shed jobs in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Ensign

item.title: The U.S. unemployment rate rose to 4.6% in November, its highest in more than four years, fueling questions about the American economy’s underlying strength
item.description: The 4.6% rate is the highest in more than four years, fueling questions about the U.S. economy’s underlying strength.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: The WSJ’s Shelby Holliday, Ashby Jones and Gunjan Banerji answered select subscriber questions about the economy during a WSJ livestream
item.description: Subscribers asked about the data sources for the report, the effect of AI on the labor market, the impact of economic uncertainty and more.
item.dc:creator: Gunjan Banerji

item.title: Eurozone Industry Extends Gains
item.description: Eurozone industrial output grew again in October, as tentative signs of a recovery in Germany eases concerns over the impact of higher U.S. tariffs on Europe’s factories.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: For decades, Tonka trucks have been a family staple and holiday stalwart. But they almost didn’t make it this year because of high tariffs.
item.description: Disrupted shipments shrank profits as the company that sells the toys to U.S. retailers awaited the outcome of trade talks.
item.dc:creator: Bob Tita

item.title: U.S. households are nearing the end of the year feeling more dour about the economy than they did at the beginning, even as they keep spending
item.description: Sentiment has neared record lows, even as spending is continuing.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: Monthly index of consumer sentiment for December from the University of Michigan rose slightly versus November, but remained much lower than where it began the year
item.description: Monthly index of consumer sentiment from the University of Michigan rose slightly versus November, but remained much lower than where it began the year.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: Eurozone Economy Posts Stronger Growth on Investment Rebound
item.description: The economy grew at a faster pace than estimated in the three months through September, aided by a pickup in investment.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Growth to Slow as Tariffs Bite, but AI Investments May Cushion the Blow
item.description: The OECD forecast the global economy to expand by 2.9% next year, a slowdown from 3.2% this year.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: China Private Gauge Signals Weaker Manufacturing Activity
item.description: Growth in China’s manufacturing production came to a halt as new orders nearly stalled last month despite a renewed rise in new orders from abroad.

item.title: U.K. Home Sales Fall on Budget Uncertainty, Report Says
item.description: Sales fell 4% across the U.K., with buyer demand down 12% on year on fears of higher property taxes in the budget, according to a report by real-estate agency Zoopla.
item.dc:creator: Ian Walker

item.title: U.S. Home Prices Slow Further Amid Affordability Concerns
item.description: The S&P Cotality Case-Shiller National Home Price Index, which measures home prices across the country, rose 1.3% in the 12 months through September. This represents the weakest performance since mid-2023.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Parts of Europe at Risk of Downward ‘Spiral’ if Older Voters Stymie Reforms, EBRD Warns
item.description: Economies that escaped from Communism are at risk if older voters and political leaders prevent changes to offset aging populations.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Threats to Eurozone Financial Stability ‘Remain Elevated,’ Says ECB’s De Guindos
item.description: A large-scale trade war has been averted, but uncertainty remains high about government policies that can affect the financial system, the European Central Bank vice president said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon
